item.title: 01 Intro
item.description:
This Workshop

The goal of this workshop is to obtain a fundamental understanding of some of the more intermediate to advanced practices of the Python Programming language.

About Me

Alex Jerez

  • Long Time Coder and Linux user
  • Launched Crosshatch: A content-sharing app, in 2011 and Zoanee Pro: A fitness membership site, in 2015
  • Currently working as a Django Backend Developer for ABI Research in Oyster Bay, NY
  • You can find me online @notalexjerez

Requirements

  • A terminal environment running Python 2.7+

  • A text editor or IDE (Sublime Text, PyCharm, etc)

  • If you’ll be connecting to our server, you will need a terminal based editor like vim, nano, emacs

Create your Environment and Activate it

$ mkvirtualenv pythonworkshop
$ workon pythonworkshop
(pythonworkshop)$

Your terminal should have (mkvirtualenv) before the dollar sign.

Now let’s go!!

item.title: 02 Data Structures
item.description:
The List

A List is an unordered list of items that can be modified (mutable). Lists might contain items of different types, but usually the items all have the same type.

common list actions:

append()
remove()
pop()
index()
reverse()

x = [3,6,8,3,8,5,35,54]

y = [[4,6,2], [7,9,4], [6,9,5]]

The Dictionary

A dictionary is an unordered set of key: value pairs

# create dictionary 'd'

d = {'firstname': 'Robert', 'age': 40, 'email': 'robert.smith@email.com'}

>>> d['firstname']
'Robert'

# use a for loop to iterate over dictionary 'd'


>>> for x in d:
...     print x
... 
age
email
firstname

# unpack d

>>> for x,y in d.items():
...     print x
...     print y
... 
age
40
email
robert.smith@email.com
firstname
Robert
>>>

The Tuple

Tuples are an ordered list of items similar to a list, but cannot be modified (immutable), and usually contains an heterogeneous sequence of elements that are accessed via unpacking rather than iterating, like with lists.

>>> x, y, z = (12345, 54321, 'hello!')
>>> x
12345
>>> y
54321
>>> z
'hello!'

item.title: 03 Classes, Functions and Methods
item.description:
Functions

a function is a reusable user-defined action.

def sayHello():
    print "Hello"

def saysomething(x):
    print x

>>> def sayHello():
...     print "Hello"
... 
>>> def saysomething(x):
...     print x
... 
>>> sayHello()
Hello
>>> saysomething("HEY")
HEY
>>>

*args and **kwargs

adding *args and **kwargs to your function lets your function accept any argument. This is helpful for when you don’t know what variables you will be expecting.

*args catches all positional arguments

**kwargs catches all the keyword arguments.

def printeverything(*args, **kwargs):
    for item in args:
        print item
    for key, value in kwargs.items():
        print key, value

This function printeverything() can now accept as many arguments and keyword arguments as you can throw at it.

def printeverything(*args, **kwargs):
    for item in args:
        print item
    for key, value in kwargs.items():
        print key, value

Classes & Methods

class TransportationVehicle(object):
     def __init__(self):
        self.wheels = None
        self.color = None
        self.brand = None

class Car(TransportationVehicle):
    def __init__(self, color, year, make):
        self.color = color
        self.year = year
        self.make = make

    def __repr__(self):
        return "this car is a %s %s %s" % (self.color,
                self.year,
                self.make)

    def about(self):
        print "this car is a %s %s %s" % (self.color,
                self.year,
                self.make)



car_one = Car("red", 2005, "Toyota")
car_two = Car("black", 2001, "Honda")

Static Methods

a static method is a function inside of your class that doesn’t depend on the class object. By adding a @staticmethod decorator to your function, it becomes a static method.

    @staticmethod
    def honk():
        print "HONK!"

Class Methods

a class method is another type of function inside of your class that has to take a class object as the first argument.

Note that this is different from accepting an instance of the class. This means that the function can return a class type that contains all the original functions and attributes.

A common use case for class methods are for initializing classes under arbitrary conditions.

@classmethod
def honkAndSay(cls, word):
    cls.honk()
    print word

item.title: 04 Errors & Exceptions
item.description:
Syntax Errors

Syntax Errors are Errors in your code that impair the Python interpreter’s ability to properly read your code.

# Example 1
#
#
#
>>> def sayHello():
...     print "hello
  File "<stdin>", line 2
    print "hello
               ^
SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal
>>> 

#
#
#
# Example 2

>>> f = []
>>> print f
[]
>>> return f
  File "<stdin>", line 1
SyntaxError: 'return' outside function

Exceptions

Exceptions happen when your code is syntactically correct, but something went wrong while the code was being executed.


# AttributeError:

>>> w = "word"
>>> w
'word'
>>> w.append('hello')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'append'


# NameError:

>>> w = "word"
>>> print r
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
NameError: name 'r' is not defined

# ZeroDivisionError:

>>> print 5/0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ZeroDivisionError: integer division or modulo by zero

Using try and finally to work around errors.

>>> phrase = "Hello"
>>> try:
...     phrase.append(" World")
... except AttributeError:
...     phrase += " World"
... 
>>> print phrase
Hello World

item.title: 05 Decorators
item.description:
A decorator is a function that takes a function and returns a modified version of it.

This can be useful for

  • wrapping a return value and do something with it

  • Checking for conditions before executing a function

The Python Django framework has some good examples of decorators:

@login_required - added to functions that return a HTTP Response, makes sure the user is logged in before sending a HTTP Response. otherwise it will return a 404 Error.

@cache_page - will cache the results of the output of the function that it decorates.

def add_exclamation(func):
    def inner(*args, **kwargs):
            result = str(func(*args, **kwargs)) + "!"
            return result
    return inner

@add_exclamation
def say(word):
    return word

def add(word):
    def wrapper(orig_func):
        def inner(*args, **kwargs):
            result = str(orig_func(*args, **kwargs)) + word
            return result
        return inner
    return wrapper

@add("?")
def sayWhat():
    return "What"

[ http://pythonhosted.org/decorator/documentation.html ]

In Python, methods are functions that expect their first parameter to be a reference to the current object. We can build decorators for methods the same way, while taking self into consideration in the wrapper function.

def p_decorate(func):
   def func_wrapper(self):
       return "<p>{0}</p>".format(func(self))
   return func_wrapper

class Person(object):
    def __init__(self):
        self.name = "John"
        self.family = "Doe"

    @p_decorate
    def get_fullname(self):
        return self.name+" "+self.family

my_person = Person()
print my_person.get_fullname()

A much better approach would be to make our decorator useful for functions and methods alike. This can be done by putting *args and **kwargs as parameters for the wrapper, then it can accept any arbitrary number of arguments and keyword arguments.

def p_decorate(func):
   def func_wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
       return "<p>{0}</p>".format(func(*args, **kwargs))
   return func_wrapper

class Person(object):
    def __init__(self):
        self.name = "John"
        self.family = "Doe"

    @p_decorate
    def get_fullname(self):
        return self.name+" "+self.family

my_person = Person()

print my_person.get_fullname()

item.title: 07 List Comprehensions
item.description:
(Excerpt from Python’s Official Documentation)

List comprehensions provide a concise way to create lists. Common applications are to make new lists where each element is the result of some operations applied to each member of another sequence or iterable, or to create a subsequence of those elements that satisfy a certain condition.

For example, assume we want to create a list of squares, like:

>>> squares = []
>>> for x in range(10):
...     squares.append(x**2)
...
>>> squares
[0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81]

We can obtain the same result with:

squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)]

A list comprehension consists of brackets containing an expression followed by a for clause, then zero or more for or if clauses. The result will be a new list resulting from evaluating the expression in the context of the for and if clauses which follow it. For example, this listcomp combines the elements of two lists if they are not equal:

>>> [(x, y) for x in [1,2,3] for y in [3,1,4] if x != y]
[(1, 3), (1, 4), (2, 3), (2, 1), (2, 4), (3, 1), (3, 4)]

and itâ€™s equivalent to:

>>>
>>> combs = []
>>> for x in [1,2,3]:
...     for y in [3,1,4]:
...         if x != y:
...             combs.append((x, y))
...
>>> combs
[(1, 3), (1, 4), (2, 3), (2, 1), (2, 4), (3, 1), (3, 4)]

Note how the order of the for and if statements is the same in both these snippets.

item.title: 11 Threading
item.description:
Global Variables

Global variables are variables that exist outside of a function that can be read and modified across multiple functions.

globvar = 0

def set_globvar_to_one():
    global globvar    # Needed to modify global copy of globvar
    globvar = 1

def print_globvar():
    print globvar     # No need for global declaration to read value of globvar

set_globvar_to_one()
print_globvar()

Unless the global variable is explicitly declared within the function as global, the global variable does not get modified anywhere outside of the scope of that function.

The Thread object

https://docs.python.org/2/library/threading.html#thread-objects 

import threading
import time

var = 0 
lock = threading.Lock()

def countTo(num):
    global var 
    for number in range(num):
        var += 1
        print var
        time.sleep(1)

def Main():
    thread1 = threading.Thread(target=countTo, args=(5,))
    thread2 = threading.Thread(target=countTo, args=(8,))
    thread1.start()
    thread2.start()

    print "Main finished"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    Main()

the Lock Object

https://docs.python.org/2/library/threading.html#lock-objects 

import threading
import time

var = 0 
lock = threading.Lock()

def countTo(num):
    global var 
    lock.acquire()
    for number in range(num):
        var += 1
        print var
        time.sleep(1)
    lock.release()
def Main():
    thread1 = threading.Thread(target=countTo, args=(5,))
    thread2 = threading.Thread(target=countTo, args=(8,))
    thread1.start()
    thread2.start()

    print "Main finished"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    Main()

item.title: 11 Argparse
item.description:
A Great exanple of the use of argparse is the django-admin.py docs:

$ django-admin.py -h
Usage: django-admin.py subcommand [options] [args]

Options:
  -v VERBOSITY, --verbosity=VERBOSITY
                        Verbosity level; 0=minimal output, 1=normal output,
                        2=verbose output, 3=very verbose output
  --settings=SETTINGS   The Python path to a settings module, e.g.
                        "myproject.settings.main". If this isn't provided, the
                        DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE environment variable will be
                        used.
  --pythonpath=PYTHONPATH
                        A directory to add to the Python path, e.g.
                        "/home/djangoprojects/myproject".
  --traceback           Raise on exception
  --no-color            Don't colorize the command output.
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit

Type 'django-admin.py help <subcommand>' for help on a specific subcommand.


import argparse

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="calculate X to the power of Y")
group = parser.add_mutually_exclusive_group()
group.add_argument("-v", "--verbose", action="store_true")
group.add_argument("-q", "--quiet", action="store_true")
parser.add_argument("x", type=int, help="the base")
parser.add_argument("y", type=int, help="the exponent")
args = parser.parse_args()
answer = args.x**args.y

if args.quiet:
    print answer
elif args.verbose:
    print "{} to the power {} equals {}".format(args.x, args.y, answer)
else:
    print "{}^{} == {}".format(args.x, args.y, answer)
